bioghist.p: The Order of the Junior Sons of America was founded in 1847 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, by Dr. Reynell Coates (1802-1886). Dr. Coates was a surgeon, scientist, statesman, naturalist, teacher, poet, lecturer and essayist, and wished to found a fraternity for American boys to serve as a "High School of American Patriotism." The organization was open to American boys aged sixteen to twenty-one years of age. Upon turning twenty-one, their membership would be transferred to the United Sons of America, the parent organization of the Junior Sons. The first meeting of the Junior Sons of America was conducted on December 10, 1847, on Ridge Road, near Spring Garden Street in Philadelphia. Towards the conclusion of the Civil War, a convention was held by several Brothers of the Junior Sons of America in Norristown, Pennsylvania, to reorganize the Order. It was at this time that the name was changed to the Patriotic Order of the Sons of America (P.O.S. of A.) and the age limit of 21 was discontinued.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of a volume of minutes of the organization's weekly meetings, for the period 1857 to 1858. The volume includes a list of committees, and the group's by-laws.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
